best. girls of herage whose parents could afford it were routinely pocked off to such comps which bore a generic resemblance to one another. they favored indian nymphs and hot hearty, energetic leaders who were called copy, skip or scottie. at these comps he learned to swim well and sail and paddle a canoe, and perhaps ride a horse or play tennis. when he weren't doing these things he would do arks on crafts and turno, dingy, lumpish clay ash trays for your mother mother smoked more back then, or bracelets made of coloured braided string. cheerfulness was required at all times even at breakfast. loat shouting and buying of spoons on the table were a load, and even encouraged at ritual intervals. chocolate bars were rationed to control tooth degant pimples. at night after supper in the dining hall or outside around the mosquito invested camp fire ring for special treats, they were singing songs. louis can still remember all the lyrics to my darling clementine and to my bonny lies over the ocean, while with acting old gestures, a rippling of the hands for the ocean, two hands together under the cheek for lies. she will never be able to forget them, which is a sad thought. louis thinks she can recognize women who went to these comps and who were good at it. they have a hardness to their hand shakes, even though a way of standing, legs planted firmly apart further than usual a way of sizing you up to see if you'd be any good in a canoe the front, not the back. they themselves would be in the back they would call it the stern. she knows that such comps still exist, ancient. its log sided buildings with the white cement in between the half logs, its flock pole ringed with whitewash stones, its weathered grey dock jutting out into late prospect, with its wooden
